description: Application for a Non-Material Amendment to Planning Permission ref: 19/00020/FUL (Demolition of existing industrial buildings and erection of replacement residential accommodation containing 79 flats, comprising of 1, 2, 3 and 4 bedroom units, a Police Office, Use Class B1 (a), residents work hub incorporating 47 car parking spaces, 184 private cycle parking spaces and 6 public cycle spaces and refuse, recycling and plant stores, a private and communal amenity spaces, play space and hard/soft landscaping (revisions submitted to show detailed design amendments) ) dated 23/01/2020. Amendments to include alterations to internal configuration and rooftop access and screens
decision_conditions: The proposed changes, including layout changes and external alterations, are materially different from the development approved by planning permission 19/00020/FUL and as such, it is recommended that the S96A application for a non-material amendment is refused.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling within the Southborough Conservation Area and is covered by an area Tree Protection order (TPO). The significance of the Southborough Conservation Area is as an area of large detached houses dating from the 1860s - 1930s surrounding Southborough House, an 1808 Grade II listed building by the architect John Nash. ProposalErection of side and rear dormer roof extensions to facilitate loft conversionConsultationTen neighbouring propeties have been notified and one objection hads been received stating;- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Noise- PrivacySurbiton Conservation Area Advisory Committee : Objection unless revised - The large windows at the proposed second storey rear are not in keeping with the existing windows in the property and will impact privacy of neighbouring properties. The proposed full width dormer roof also impacts adversely the front elevation of the property and is not in context with the other properties in the street.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on the Southborough Conservation Area; and,- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed flat roof Dutch barn style side dormer roof extension would not complement the character of the original dwelling. It would appear incongruous and jarring in appearance from the street and to the original property by way of its overall design.  It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.The proposed development is therefore considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be an adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer Comment: As stated above, it is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals. Officers consider that this adverse impact would amount to less than substantial harm to the significance of the Southborough Conservation Area. It is therefore necessary to weigh this harm against any public benefits of the proposal. No public benefits to outweigh the identified harm have been proposed nor are there any obvious to officers.Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments: No Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021). Therefore, it has not been demonstrated that the proposals would achieve the highest standards of fire safety.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

I acknowledge receipt of your payment for £ 203.50, the fee required for this application is £231, therefore please forward the outstanding balance of £27.50 as soon as possible.Note: Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.
